newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - Jan 27.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - Jan 27.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-Consumers are not assured of low rates just because the Metropolitan Waterworks and Sewerage System has been privatised, Senator Ernesto Herrera said. (PHILIPPINE DAILY INQUIRER)
- Three more measles patients died Saturday at the San Lazaro Hospital, bringing to 39 the death toll since January 1. (THE MANILA TIMES)

- Detained Zamboanga congressman Romeo Jalosjos said he would ask for a postponement of his arraignment for at least one week pending resolution by the Court of Appeals of his petition for an injunction on the arrest warrants isssued against him by the Makati Regional Trial Court. (THE PHILIPPINE STAR)

- Newly elected Thai Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh arrives in Manila on Wednesday for a two-day state visit aimed at reinvigorating his country's relations with the Philippines, especially in the area of investments. (THE PHILIPPINE JOURNAL)

-President Fidel Ramos justified the privatisation of the Manila water service, saying the government has not completely given away its right to supervise the two firms tasked to distribute water for the metropolis. (THE MANILA CHRONICLE)
- Executive Secretary Ruben Torres said the government saw no need for the intervention of Indonesia in a peace settlement with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front. (MANILA STANDARD)

- The Philippine Central Bank has warned the Bureau of Internal Revenues that it will not withold interest income from reverse repurchase agreements in the absence of a BIR governing circular on the controversial tax. (THE BUSINESS DAILy)
- The Department of Energy lifted a moratorium on the acceptance and processing of applications from private sector firms to put up power plants in the country. (THE MANILA CHRONICLE)

- Ayala Corp, one of the two groups which won last week's waterworks bidding, said it expects to incur losses in the first few years of the 25-year concession period but hopes to make money eventually. (THE MANILA TIMES).

- Barely three months into a new administration, the Philippine Stock Exchange is being rocked with resignations, making many believe that the unified exchange may be heading for a difficult year. (TODAY)
